title.value: Rapidly Inferring Personalized Neurostimulation Parameters with Meta-Learning: A Case Study of Individualized Fiber Recruitment in Vagus Nerve Stimulation
title.justification: This title is taken directly from the research paper, ensuring accurate representation of the source.
title.quote: Rapidly Inferring Personalized Neurostimulation Parameters with Meta-Learning: A Case Study of Individualized Fiber Recruitment in Vagus Nerve Stimulation

extractions.description: This paper proposes a meta-learning framework to rapidly optimize personalized neurostimulation parameters, focusing on the physiological modeling of fiber recruitment during vagus nerve stimulation (VNS). The framework leverages past data to improve efficiency in new subject parameter fitting, demonstrating effectiveness on both experimental and synthetic datasets.

type.justification: The research empirically tests the proposed meta-learning framework on both real experimental data and synthetic datasets to validate its performance.
type.quote: Using additional synthetic data sets to complement experimental results, we demonstrate that our meta-learning framework is capable of directly modeling the physiology-eCAP relationship for individual subjects with much fewer individually queried data points than standard methods.

name.justification: The primary focus of the study is on optimizing parameters for neurostimulation treatments using deep learning techniques.
name.quote: Neurostimulation is emerging as treatment for several diseases of the brain and peripheral organs. Due to variability arising from placement of stimulation devices, underlying neuroanatomy and physiological responses to stimulation, it is essential that neurostimulation protocols are personalized to maximize efficacy and safety.

name.justification: The study introduces and evaluates a meta-learning framework for optimizing neurostimulation parameters, making it a sub-research field.
name.quote: To address that need, we propose a meta-learning family of algorithms to conduct few-shot optimization of key fitting parameters of physiological responses in new individuals.

name.justification: The paper discusses few-shot learning techniques as part of the meta-learning framework to improve the efficiency of parameter optimization.
name.quote: Few-shot learning [7,8] is a widely studied learning paradigm in machine learning, where the learning model is asked to solve each task while observing only a small fractions of the data.

name.justification: The model is identified in the paper as a core component of the proposed meta-learning framework with Gaussian Process as the population model.
name.quote: meta-learning framework with GP as population model

is_contributed.justification: The paper proposes this model as part of its contribution to the field.
is_contributed.quote: meta-learning framework with GP as population model

is_executed.justification: The model is evaluated through various experiments as described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: we demonstrate that our meta-learning framework is capable of directly modeling the physiology-eCAP relationship for individual subjects with much fewer individually queried data points than standard methods.

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared to other models in the study.
is_compared.quote: Using additional synthetic data sets to complement experimental results, we demonstrate that our meta-learning framework is capable of directly modeling the physiology-eCAP relationship for individual subjects with much fewer individually queried data points than standard methods.

name.justification: The paper mentions using PyTorch for implementing the meta-learning framework.
name.quote: We implemented the proposed meta-learning framework in Python. PyTorch [32] packages BoTorch [33] and GpyTorch [34] were utilized to perform BO and GP respectively.
